data.text: Repacking the Tent? Tent Does Not Fit Back Into Its Bag

Last night, I struck a BIG entry off my bucket list and camped in a tent for night. Epic, I know. I am frustrated, though, that the tent, which seemed so compact and manageable when I brought it home, doesn’t even come close to being able to fit back into its carry bag after just one use. Is this typical, or is there a trick I should know? There’s no way this thing is fitting on my rear rack anymore!
How did you attempt to put it back in? Did you fold or stuff?
data.author: Landy Figueroa

data.text: Put a picture of the tent one of us will know how to repack it. It's normally relatively easy to get them back into the sack.
data.author: John Axson

data.text: I find that there's always too much room in the bag once I've repacked it😂
data.author: Clive Beach
Diane Belanger

data.text: Pack poles separately, put tent in a stuff sack
data.author: Sista Maxine

data.text: Usually a tight roll works for me. But there are a great number of stuff sacks one could use. Could just snag one that's just slightly bigger than the the original sack.
data.author: Aaron Crawford

data.text: If it came out it should go back in . Roll it really tightly, making sure all the air is out . What make of tent ? What type of bag does it go into ?
data.author: Peter Couttie

data.text: I never attempt to put the tent back into the normal stuff sack. Actually I don’t put much back into stuff sacks. My tent and fly just get stuffed into a pannier. Poles and pegs get strapped to my bars or rack in their own stuff sack.
data.author: Shawn Lund

data.text: I stuff the tent in the bag, then the fly and then place the folded ground sheet over the top just inside the bag and tighten. I store the tent poles separately in a dry sac with a few other odds and ends on my rear rack.
data.author: Rhonda Klann Leduc

data.text: Tent usually isn't the problem in re-packing. . .sleeping bag on the other hand. Step-by-step instructions. 1) strike tent. 2) lay the fabric parts down and fold them to the width of the collapsed tent poles. 3) put the collapsed tent poles at one end of the fabric and roll the tent around the tent poles. Give the air time to escape. 4) unroll 5) re-roll the tent around the tent poles. 99.999% of the time it will be compact enough to fit into its stuff sack with room for tent stakes, ground cloth, stake hammer. Instructions for putting sleeping bag back into its original stuff sack: You can't! the people who pack sleeping bags have PhDs in Material Packing, access to steam rollers and hydraulic rammers. Buy a slightly larger stuff sack.
data.author: Craig D Bersak

data.text: It’s a cheapo Ozark 3-person tent that I thought I’d give way after one use. But I loved camping in it so much, I want to keep it!
data.author: Tom Montalbano

data.text: If you like it, just get a bigger bag for it. Ortlieb has great options in all sizes.
data.author: Thomas Arson

data.text: , I agree with Thomas. I have a dry bag that easily takes tent, sleeping bag and mat….no morning struggles. Just stick them in and strap them bag on top of the rear rack.
data.author: Bryan A West

data.text: My rear rack is already fully occupied by a Topeak trunk bag with pop-out panniers.
data.author: Tom Montalbano

data.text: My tent is the same way- you've got to roll it up perfectly for it to go back into its bag. Ain't nobody got time or patience for doing a perfectly pressed roll while kneeling in the dirt. It just gets flapped out and stuffed into a pannier.
data.author: Braden Graham

data.text: I have the exact tent and been using it for 3 years now. I treated it when I first bought it and it hasn’t leaked! But sucks in high wind! Take your time rolling it up you my have to do it twice! I get it in a 10 Ltr. Dry bag!
data.author: Jim M. Leone

data.text: Lots of practice, and a touch of luck.
data.author: Chuck Brooks

data.text: You should have practiced packing it before leaving 🤣😂
data.author: George Homer

data.text: Thanks. That’s just the answer I needed.
data.author: Tom Montalbano

data.text: its ok....youre not the only one....but yeah it helps to paractice packing and unpacking all your gear a few times before your trips ;)
data.author: George Homer

data.text: Seems like that’s exactly what Tom’s doing? On a car camping trip to test the gear and process before going on a bike trip. Many helpful answers here, yours isn’t one.
data.author: Colin Milne

data.text: learn to read thats not what i said to do.....i said before leaving the house you need to practice packing your gear...car or bike....
data.author: George Homer

data.text: interesting. Didn’t see the house mentioned even once in your post, perhaps try not to miss important facts in your future posts to avoid looking like a knob? Although based on the substance of your post it’s possibly impossible.
data.author: Colin Milne

data.text: i clearly stated " before leaving" which clearly implies practice at home
data.author: George Homer

data.text: you seem to be trying not to comprehend the english language lol
data.author: George Homer

data.text: you must look in the mirror before calling others knobs when in fact you are the one...lol
data.author: George Homer

data.text: 😂
data.author: Colin Milne

data.text: Air is you enemy. Every time a tiny pocket of air is included in the pack the volume increases. Really focus on the tightness of the roll and squeezing the air out as you roll. Makes a massive difference.
data.author: Jon Slade

data.text: Try stuffing it in firmly rather than rolling. Rolling wears the same parts of the fabric repeatedly. You can pack fairly tightly that way and you extend the life of your tent. Plus shake and stuff , no time wasted folding.
data.author: Robert Crow

data.text: Start your tent roll by laying your pole bag on one end and tightly roll tent with the pole bag. Gets it really tight.
data.author: Kelly Milbrath

data.text: Don't roll the tent. Stuff it in the bag
data.author: Jake Klamerus

data.text: The cheaper the tent, the lower the odds to ever get it back into the bag.
data.author: Thomas Arson

data.text: How'd you pack it back up?
data.author: Brian Halley

data.text: I just threw it all in aplastic bin. This time, I had the option of putting it back in the car, but next time, I plan take it on my bicycle.
data.author: Tom Montalbano

data.text: if you fold on the seems that's usually your best bet
data.author: Brian Halley

data.text: It's called a stuff sack for a reason! Keep, going, kneel on it and it will all go in eventually.
data.author: Malcolm Frost

data.text: Never fit again..lol
data.author: Claudia Jones

data.text: Just make a slightly bigger stuff sack for it. Or buy one. They are usually a dime a dozen on the internet. Just measure your existing on and 10 per cent to the volume.
data.author: Douglas Thompson

data.text: Generally that’s how it goes. I’ve seen videos of people buying tents and the bags have ways to remove a seam or something that expands the bag, but never seen those in real life.
data.author: Dustin Noslo

data.text: I separate everything. Keep the stakes, ropes, and poles in a mesh bag, tied up tight. The body (mesh part, bottom) in the original stuff sack. (assuming it did not get wet overnight or you can dry it off before putting in the stuff sack). The rain fly, I keep in a separate mesh sack. Some or all of these can go in a dry bag, if they are dry. It not dry, I want to keep them on by bike where they can dry out every day.
data.author: Andrew Hill

data.text: You can also buy a compression bag with straps that can be tightened to make the package more compact. Otherwise you need to practice more at home before the next adventure.
data.author: Jenny Currie

data.text: Maybe the make? Mine goes back in fine, never had any issues. A in the past I have had to re roll a couple of times
data.author: Rachel Katherine

data.text: Roll it up tightly with the tent poles inside. They’ll also serve as a guide to the width of the supplied bag it goes in.
data.author: Tim Holman

data.text: This is why I have compression straps.
data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text: Tight roll towards the opening so the air escape. Slow and deliberate
data.author: Mick Newman

data.text: Try pick up the newish MSR tent bags ‘ingenious’ and very lightweight. Tents go in easy no matter what as they open right up lengthways and are extra generous then compress with the straps. I’ve have the MSR Access 2. (Well one of my tents) I wish I had a few more of there bags. (Unless you happen to have some massive tent)?
data.author: Thomas Magowan O'Moore

data.text: It’s a $28 vinyl Walmart tent that advertises for three but really fits one.
data.author: Tom Montalbano

data.text: Ah.. figures.. just find any bigger bag I think..
data.author: Thomas Magowan O'Moore

data.text: I had this tent! Well, the same thing from another box store (Academy Sports). When you first open your tent, pay close attention to how it’s folded. You don’t have to fold it perfectly on the creases, but close enough. And roll it as tight as you can, that is key! When you tie the lashings around the tent, it may have some squish but shouldn’t ballon at all. As you get to the end of rolling it up, go slow and let the last of the air escape. It seems tedious, but it’s not so bad really
data.author: Nesta Skychild

data.text: Ps. Otherwise don’t be too particular with the folding.. ‘stuff’ it in on your trip till you get home. Then you can dry, fold & store. 👍
data.author: Thomas Magowan O'Moore

data.text: It came out, it goes back in. Practice, practice, practice.
data.author: John Boyle

data.text: #thatswhatshesaid
data.author: Aaron Crawford

data.text: All part of the fun 😝
data.author: Amtrak Jez

data.text: I only stow my tent in the original bag when I put it away after hanging out to dry when the adventure is over. I usually stow my tent, ground cloth, pillow, sleeping pad and pump in one compression bag. The bag gets strapped to my front rack. The poles and tent stakes live in my pannier in front.
data.author: Moe Langford

data.text: I have to look into these “compression bags,” I guess. But first, I need to settle on a more permanent tent.
data.author: Tom Montalbano

data.text: the bag has four straps that you pull to compress to a smaller size. Mine is waterproof, I also have one for my sleeping bag to keep it dry. Sea to summit has them. I got mine from REI at their big yearly sale.
data.author: Moe Langford

data.text: Trust me when I saw Many many of us have been there .... A lot of tents come with folding instructions ..... usually fold into a triangle and roll up---and it takes as much care or more than folding a giant map or anything else. Definitely want to practice because early in the morning, cold and damp and stiff and pre-coffee, the thing acts like it is actively fighting you ..... Stuff sack might work but the tent might not be as readily compressible as the insulation of a sleeping bag so it still might not fit. Best bet (in my experience) is to learn to fold and roll it.
data.author: Chris Jasurek

data.text: I just plain old STUFF my tent, rainfly and footprint into the/a bag... Fits in MUCH better and doesn't hurt the tent! Way better than folding or rolling!
data.author: Mark Dante

data.text: I'd be careful about rolling and compressing too much as the hooks or other harder elements of the tent could end up damaging the fine mosquito net mesh parts of the tent. Just find a bigger bag or no bag at all. You can roll it up and fasten it in that (gently but firm) shape with a couple of Velcro straps. They sell Velcro by the meter and it comes in quite handy sometimes.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: Tents are stored in a stuff sack for a reason. Don't try and refold it onstead just grab a handful and start stuffing it. Stuff the door area ladt so excess air can be pushed out. If you fold it the same way you'll put excess wear along the same seams. Hope this helps.
data.author: Rick Hancock

data.text: Stuff it into the stuff sack. That's why it's called a stuff sack
data.author: Tom Kerrigan

data.text: So I know this sounds kinda dumb, but it works great. When I first buy a tent, I grab a marker and mark lines on it where it folds so it fits back in the stuff sack. Then it’s just a matter of rolling it tightly to push out all the air. Works great and never have an issue getting them back into those stupid undersized bags!
data.author: Doug Speer

data.text: I thought you’d bought yourself a bucket at first 😜🤣
data.author: Richard Smith

data.text: Ha ha you only a true camper , when you get it back in its bag . Try getting all the trapped air out the tent when folding or rolling it up . make sure final fold length ,closely mutchs the length of the bag . Practice makes perfect
data.author: Garth Berry

data.text: I agree that they'll never be as compact after use, but with carefully folding/rolling and a little practice any tent I've ever had did go back in its bag
data.author: Charlotte Kramer

data.text: If it came out it will go back in. Just stuff it in there, no need to fold.
data.author: Fred Dixon

data.text: gotta roll it up as tight as possible. use your knees
data.author: Tdogg Tdogg

data.text: As others have said, that can be a challenge when your knees are in the mud and everything is coated in campsite talt.
data.author: Tom Montalbano

data.text: Typically lay the bag by the tent. Fold the tent in thirds to fit length wise into the bag. Lay the tent poles on one end of tent. Roll the tent tightly around the tent stakes while pushing excess air out of the tent while rolling. It should fit back in the bag nicely. If all else fails, find a boyscout meeting or eagle scout. They have rolled up many tents by the time they reach eagle scout. They can probably help you learn to roll the tent to fit back in the bag.
data.author: Barnes Margy

data.text: Planned obsolescence.
data.author: Kenneth Paul

data.text: I never have a problem with tents. It's compact sleeping bags, especially the down one I have for autumn/early spring. It's like trying to fit an elephant into the are-se of an ant.
data.author: Chris Power

data.text: Chris Power hilarious description. You must be trying to roll the bag. Don't, just stuff it in, and use your feet or knees to hold the stuff bag still or its like giving a pill to a cat.
data.author: Gracie Trish

data.text: I do that, but for a first thing in the morning chore it's a 'mare. All other packing is pretty much simple and quick, except that. It's a Critereon traveller 650, so not the lightest or smallest, but nice and toasty Purchased because the old two season i used didn't cut the mustard when mornings got frosty.
data.author: Chris Power

data.text: I love motels and B & B's!!!!
data.author: Dale Lindsey

data.text: They fit....just need to practice.
data.author: Dan Wille

data.text: I agree with everyone, you have to roll it perfectly. The frustrating part is the air that gets trapped, and the water if it’s raining 🙂
data.author: Jorge Mark Fitzgerald

data.text: I use 2 4L dry bags. One for the tent and one for the fly. That way if the fly is damp, it doesn’t get the tent wet. I have the MSR hubba hubba so I can set up the fly first if it’s raining and keep my tent dry. The foot print switches back and forth between bags depending if it’s damp or not too. I strap the poles on the back rack.
data.author: Karley Finnegan

data.text: Nice outfit -;～
data.author: Brandy Hostin

data.text: Huh?
data.author: Tom Montalbano
